subject: [Lab 02] Q6: Lambda the Environment Diagram
content:
Q6: Lambda the Environment Diagram

Please post all questions you have below concerning Q6: Lambda the Environment Diagram in the follow-ups.

If you are stuck on this question, feel free to read through the follow-up responses to see if you can draw any ideas from them.

threads.question: When does a new frame get created in an environment diagram? Is it after an entire call expression is evaluated (operator and operand(s) )? Thanks!

follow-ups.feedback: A new frame gets created when a function call is executed. For instance, if I write `print(1, print(2))` the first frame will be created for the `print(2)` execution since this function call gets executed due to the operands being evaluated.

threads.question: Are there answers to this section somewhere or no?

follow-ups.feedback: Running the code into [Online Python Tutor](http://pythontutor.com/composingprograms.html#mode=edit) with "Visualize Execution" will give you a step by step solution to the environmental diagram.

threads.question: For the first question, why is k=9 in f2? ![](/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&prefix=attach%2Fjziyku5gomy7aq%2Fjl4fp2t7ly83vq%2Fk0hhor4ovsq9%2FScreen_Shot_20190912_at_7.14.26_PM.png)

follow-ups.feedback: The function returned by `make_adder` (defined by the lambda expression in line 3) gets called in line 5 and takes in `n` as its input, and the lambda binds its input to the name `k`.

threads.question: Why is f3 lambda? Shouldnâ€™t it be b?

follow-ups.feedback: No, the function bound to `b` _globally_ only executes once. Make sure you examine what gets re-bound within the body of the global function `b`.
